text: and the Amish community outside the
eastern Ohio town of bear Colts life
seems to follow familiar patterns the
children's play in front of the school
at recess and inside the farms main
house the women gather for a regular
meeting better naira worry is palpable
as a day of reckoning approaches 416
community members who may face long
prison sentences Wilma mullet who was
not charged says she is seeking refuge
in her faith it's in my mind every day
to pray for a miracle that my dad won't
get life in prison and the men won't get
won't get such a hard sentence in
September Sam mullet leader of the
isolated bear called settlement was
convicted along with his followers on
felony charges including conspiracy and
hate crimes in late 2011 the ten men and
six women forcibly cut the beards and
hair of outside Amish who they saw as
critics and who they thought needed to
be taught a lesson the Amish have no
tradition of cutting beards and hair as
a punishment or a means of atonement the
bear Colts Amish say they started the
practice among themselves in 2010 Wilma
mullet and a friend cut her brothers
beard and that of six other men on the
farm who they accused of mistreating
their families and having impure
thoughts now they look like a young boy
again and it gives em a fresh start
they're going to start over they're
going to start a new life but later Beck
holds residents attacked people from
outside Amish communities shearing the
beards and long hair that are central to
Amish identity the five assaults spread
terror among the Amish of eastern Ohio
we made a mistake we're not saying that
we didn't do anything wrong we made a
mistake during the trial prosecutors
also presented evidence that Sam mullet
engaged in intimate sexual quote
counseling with female followers mullet
has denied the charge
his wife Martha mullet says that long
prison sentences seem unfair considering
that none of the victims suffered
lasting harm their hair will grow back
your beards will grow back they could go
on with their lives but their want they
want to tear our lives apart the
community has become closer since the
men were sent to jail says Martha mullet
and they are preparing in advance for
bad news we could pull together and all
help each other we have made plans what
we want to do with the children of the
parents that will both be in jail Wilma
mullet says the community will remain
faithful to Sam
her father no matter if he gets life in
prison he's still going to be our bishop
here he's going to help us with
everything if my mind goes that they
will get like maybe 15 or 17 years and
then my mind can't think anymore
I can't think that far it hurts too much
the convicted men and women are
scheduled to be sentenced on February 8
this is Erica comb of the New York Times
